Award.AwardTitle: Strongly Coupled Fluid-Structure Interaction with Application to Blood Flow in Deformable Arteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to overcome the deficiencies of the currently used computational technologies by developing spectral/hp finite elements with least-squares formulation and algorithms. The physical interaction of fluids and solids is of practical significance in various branches of engineering. Examples include flutter of aerodynamic structures, structural deformation due to explosions, vortex induced vibrations of sub-sea pipelines and risers, inflatable dams, parachute dynamics, and blood flow through arteries. Since fluids and solids are described by different sets of equations, they are solved independently and the tractions calculated from the fluid flow equations is used as applied force on the structure. Geometric changes of the structure due to the tractions in turn influences the flow characteristics. This two-way coupling can be significant when high-speed flows and/or geometrically complex structures are involved. The present study employs a single computational framework that allows for enhanced compatibility and accuracy in the physical coupling of the fluid and solid. The coupling between the fluid and solid is enforced using implicit strongly coupled partitioned procedures. Blood flow through deformable arteries will be used as a benchmark problem.

The developed computational framework has the potential to transform, for example, diagnostic capabilities for the initiation and propagation of blood-related diseases, and aerospace structures design. The research will also revamp some of the courses in structural mechanics and computational methods to include approaches to study fluid-solid interaction problems and enable students to find accurate solutions to societal challenges in designing systems involving fluid-solid couplings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The physical interaction of fluid and solid media in vortex-induced vibration, flutter of aircraft structures, and blood flow through arteries is of importance. This project explored both theoretical and computational approaches to study the interactions and their influence on the response of structures. In particular, the influence of a surrounding fluid medium on the vibration and transient response of beam and plate structures is studied. Both classical and shear deformable beam and plate theories were considered in this work. The results led to the finding that the fluid-structure interaction has significant effect on the vibration and transient response. The effect is to damp the response, depending on geometry, material properties, and boundary conditions.

Simplifying assumptions were made to formulate a one-dimensional model of blood flow through arteries.  The material of the artery is treated as linearly elastic and the cross-sectional area is taken as a variable to determine the flow rate and velocity field. Further study in this area is needed to improve the model to represent more realsitic geometries and the heterogeneous nature of the arterial wall.

Also, two monolithic, multi-time-stepping schemes (for transient analysis) for first-order and second-order systems are developed. The robustness of the developed schemes is also illustrated through one- and two-dimensional problems. These schemes are general and applicable to a variety of physical systems.These schemes were investigated for conditions under which they are energy-preserving.

In addition, diffusion of concentration of chemical species is studied. The role of h and p mesh refinements on satisfying the non-negative constraint and maximum principle is investigated.

As a part of the research project 5 Ph.D. students, 2 M.S. students, and one undergraduate student were trained in the topics of fluid-solid interaction, finite element modeling, and multi-time-step algorithms. Numerous archival journal papers coauthored with the graduate students on various topics studied during this project were either published or  accepted for publication.

The research also led to the discussion and inclusion of topics for graduate courses. The PIs integrated the technical formulations and computational schemes developed during the prsent research project into their graduate courses.

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2015
Modified by: Junuthula N Reddy
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The physical interaction of fluid and solid media in vortex-induced vibration, flutter of aircraft structures, and blood flow through arteries is of importance. This project explored both theoretical and computational approaches to study the interactions and their influence on the response of structures. In particular, the influence of a surrounding fluid medium on the vibration and transient response of beam and plate structures is studied. Both classical and shear deformable beam and plate theories were considered in this work. The results led to the finding that the fluid-structure interaction has significant effect on the vibration and transient response. The effect is to damp the response, depending on geometry, material properties, and boundary conditions. Simplifying assumptions were made to formulate a one-dimensional model of blood flow through arteries. The material of the artery is treated as linearly elastic and the cross-sectional area is taken as a variable to determine the flow rate and velocity field. Further study in this area is needed to improve the model to represent more realsitic geometries and the heterogeneous nature of the arterial wall. Also, two monolithic, multi-time-stepping schemes (for transient analysis) for first-order and second-order systems are developed. The robustness of the developed schemes is also illustrated through one- and two-dimensional problems. These schemes are general and applicable to a variety of physical systems.These schemes were investigated for conditions under which they are energy-preserving. In addition, diffusion of concentration of chemical species is studied. The role of h and p mesh refinements on satisfying the non-negative constraint and maximum principle is investigated. As a part of the research project 5 Ph.D. students, 2 M.S. students, and one undergraduate student were trained in the topics of fluid-solid interaction, finite element modeling, and multi-time-step algorithms. Numerous archival journal papers coauthored with the graduate students on various topics studied during this project were either published or accepted for publication. The research also led to the discussion and inclusion of topics for graduate courses. The PIs integrated the technical formulations and computational schemes developed during the prsent research project into their graduate courses.
